review: I am so emo right now.Kate and Tully withstand every battle the universe throws at them as they stand hand-in-hand through over thirty years of friendI am so emo right now.Kate and Tully withstand every battle the universe throws at them as they stand hand-in-hand through over thirty years of friendship. God damn, that's a long time, and I don't think I'd be able to do it myself but nonetheless.... When the two first meet at the age of 14, Kate is awestruck by how cool Tully is. She knows what clothes to wear and what kids to talk to so that the crown of popularity can grace her head within the first few days of moving to her town. While it's true Tully is cool, she's not exactly content with her life. Seeing her new neighbor Kate and family eating dinner every night all happy together makes her feelings of inadequacy toward having a stoner mom exacerbated. But after a rough night, Tully opens up to Kate and befriends her. Their story unfolds from there.Of course, the dichotomy between the two girls did not just disappear when they vowed to stay friends forever -- rather, it manifests in quite harmful ways. Although the two internally care for each other, many writers would argue that one of the hallmarks of female friendship is this simultaneous presence of love and resentment. TullyandKate toe the line like it's the only thing they know how to do. After all, it is one of the only character traits they have in common. I am truly at a lack of words trying to express how wonderful this book was. As we travel through time and grow up with the girls, the book metamorphoses. At first, it takes one form we grow to become familiar with, but so seamlessly, it melds into another. Without even noticing, you've reached the final pages and realized you've read a book that's turned from childhood innocence to envious relationships to loving families. I feel like I've lived a LIFE, only to realize I've just read it through someone else's eyes. I don't know. I really don't know. I audibly sobbed my way through the last 50 pages, and no book has ever come close to leaving me like that (runners-up are The Great Alone and The Nightingale, which, not coincidentally, happen to also be written by Kristin Hannah. I love that woman.)While I will mention that Tully and Kate sometimes feel like caricatures of certain personality traits, I don't think it detracts from the book too far. Often times, their stubbornness to grow is what prompts issues in their life to arise and reveals the effect each of them have on the other. Perhaps, it can feel like a bit of an exaggeration, but the consequences are all fluid. They make sense. And one can only read the full story to understand what happens from there.But I would recommend this a million times over. To those who enjoy the journey. To people who need to apologize and people who need to forgive. And to any woman ever. This is the female friendship wrapped up in a pretty little package. People fail to find the essence but it's marketed as that anyway. What I've seen is that they take the most shocking parts of it all and chalk it up to be the highlights, even though, in reality, they probably wouldn't even make the reel. This is a rant about me being told that this book was a horror because it was much less like that and much more like a Moshfegh -- sorry guys. Death In Her Hands type beat. But let me not get distracted. As always, a plot lowdown: Upon her husband (Ralph)'s mother's suicide, protagonist and narrator Abby rejoices over the fact that she no longer has to deal with offhand remarks about her character in a manner so delightful that could win her the motherly love she so always longed for...because that was never going to work anyway. Abby steals the ring off her late mother-in-law's finger while her body is in the hospital. She buries it in the yard, hoping to bring it back up to Ralph when she's finished grieving, like "Oh! I just found this what!" Maybe he'll give her the ring that his mother refused to pass down to her. But things get weird as Ralph starts noticing his mother around the house -- what could she be back for? After long pages of rambling from an insecure woman (which I get, I don't blame her), I started thinking to myself, "How does one define horror?" And then I got to the climax and thought to myself "Ahhh. I think I get it now." In the middle of multiple "wtf just happened" moments of the final pages, I had to try to analyze what literally any of it meant. What I've deduced is that author Hogarth is examining a woman's desire to be a good mother, whether that be instigated by society or childhood trauma (or is it innate? Bc if so, evolution skipped that one out on me). And in being the perfect mother, you must also be the perfect wife. But even if you try your darndest to fit this mold, you'll still get flak from the people you're supposed to call your loved ones. You're not a good mother. No one is.So is the only good mother a dead one? The one who, in her absence, is absolutely incapable of making mistakes, or causing conflict? Hogarth's diction is masterfully chosen to communicate all these things. The word "baby" is stretched to its edges as all its different meanings are used in close proximity to each other, whether it's to describe a lover or a yet-to-be-conceived child. It makes you feel disgusted, but I can't believe someone was capable of making me feel that way with only one word. I don't know. I'll leave you with this quote to think about."But now [Ralph's mother] was quiet, now that she might be gone, Ralph was being pummeled by the full typhoon of his love for her, one of life's cruelest tricks, that the extent of this love waits to reveal itself." Your classic haunted house story takes a turn as these interconnected plots jump 9 years forward each time to give you another mini-story that serves as a puzzle piece for the audience. I'll spare you the dirty details for the sake of your enjoyment... but if you've read this, please message me. I need someone to talk to about it. Every single time I thought I had a well-rounded idea of where the story was going to go, I was completely swept off the Earth's axis. At first, I assumed the novel would follow the first person, Nathan's, perspective for its entirety, but I was a bit disappointed when I was proved wrong -- for his storytelling remains my favorite out of all of them.But that is not to say that the others were terrible! No no NO they were far from it. Each of the characters were SO distinct. Little nuances appeared across them that differentiated the present perspective from the last, and I am truly in awe at Mitchell's mastery in giving each character their own voice. I don't know how he managed to get inside the head of each one. It's like he knew them. It felt raw and authentic, as though the story was being told to me by the character themselves.I think it's important to note that the final act references Mitchell's The Bone Clocks, which I'm very regretful for not having read prior to this. I’m going to say one thing right off the bat: after reading the masterpiece that is Disorientation by Elaine Hsieh Chou, which has VERY similar themes to this book, Yellowface simply could not measure up to me. In that novel, stolen Asian literature is tackled both so maturely and humorously in a way that makes it feel like the pinnacle of modern satire. R.F. Kuang’s approach to this was surely unique: writing from the white woman’s perspective, a task that was likely challenging considering she had to prioritize humanizing the main character while pointing out her flaws. There were a lot of great questions opened up here — who has the right to tell certain stories? when does inspiration become stealing? do white men fetishize their asian partners? and the like. Yet, I feel as though the answers to these questions weren’t explored as deeply as they could have been. This novel was tied so closely to the plot (mainly a lot of insight into the publishing process) that any actual thesis wasn’t backed up with much contextual evidence. I just could not stop thinking about how much more masterfully these ideas were examined in Disorientation. I wish I didn’t have to compare, but these are my thoughts! Otherwise, the book was compulsively readable. Yes, I was entertained, but for an author of Kuang’s status, I was just expecting so much more. While I was not on Earth, I read Cannery Row by John Steinbeck. Sure, it was for my English class, but I read it nonetheless. I did skim through bits and pieces of this novel when it was required reading for my English class in my junior year of high school, 3 years ago, and I guess I kinda remember having some lengthy discussions on it -- but nothing I ever paid much attention to. This time around, I actually digested the words on the paper!! That truly doesn't happen too often… unless the book actually interests me. 3 years ago, I didn't care. Now, I do.I think this novel came to me again in a time where I learned to appreciate the simplicity of things. I have become much more accustomed to reading novels that allow the stories to crawl out on their own (here am I paraphrasing Steinbeck himself), much like most of my new favorite books in the literary fiction genre. Since books like these don't tend to have a very strong plotline, I was happy to just float along and indulge in all of the shenanigans that ensued in Monterey in the mid-20th century, from catching frogs to throwing parties. Interspersed with chapters of fables or smaller stories about other people in town, it felt relaxing, like a breath of fresh air.I want to commend Steinbeck on his ability to drop minute details about the characters without going into further depth. What he wants us to know we will know, but other information will be kept hidden unless the need for it arises later on. It makes the reader question the contents of the characters' pasts: what happened that made them end up like this? But I do think a bit too much consideration on this topic will make for a less enjoyable read. We don't need to rack our brains to answer the mysteries of the story when we can instead sit back and watch. Just one more thing I wanted to note: I didn't entirely like the characterization of Asian characters in this novel, from "the old Chinaman" to Lee Chong. If you were a younger reader, do be wary about that, but that’s not to say the book is useless without personal relation. As I flipped through the pages, I was met with more post-ironic imitations of memes and things you would see posted on the portal. Some half-assed political commentary was made and then we moved on to the protagonist’s “irl” struggles. Some readers may say that this book was able to tackle “deep” issues posed by the portal and question what the modern age is coming to, but I would disagree. Unlike the title of the book suggests, nearly every point that Lockwood made has been made before. Honestly, everyone I know is talking about this. The internet sucks, and it’s ruining our perception of the real world and our interaction in relationships. What else do you have to offer? I have to say that most commentary that arose from this book came from quite a privileged and white perspective. Of course, there’s nothing wrong with providing that kind of viewpoint to the conversation, but it ends up being an incredibly lackluster reading experience in the kind of novel that should challenge the structure of today’s society. What do we have so far? Too little social criticism, and now I bring you too much fragmentary writing. I will say that this is more of a personal opinion, but I could not dive into Lockwood’s novel as deeply as I could have because almost every paragraph is separated by 3 little dots aligned in the middle of the page.
